title: 15 Online Side Jobs You Can Start Without Any Skills or Money
description: No experience? No cash? Not a problem. These 15 online jobs can help beginners make real money online without having to pay for anything up front.
alt: Person working on laptop from home doing side hustles

content.text: Want to make money online but don't have any special skills or money to start? The good news is that you don't need either. There are many side jobs you can do from your phone or laptop, even if you're just starting out. You just need to be consistent, want to learn, and spend a few minutes a day. In fact, millions of people just like you are already making extra money this way and you can too.

Online hustles are great because they make things fair for everyone. There's something here for everyone, whether you're a student, a stay at home parent, a retiree, or just someone who wants to get away from the 9-to-5 grind. You don't need a degree, fancy equipment, or even an upfront investment. All you need is your time, a smartphone or computer, and an internet connection.
Why These Hustles Are Good for Newbies

Before we get into the list, let's talk about why these hustles are great for people who are just starting out. First, it's easy to get started with them; anyone can sign up and start right away. Second, they let you choose when you want to work, so you can fit it in with your other commitments. Third, they offer chances to learn that can help you get better-paying jobs in the future. You can use these as steps to build your confidence, learn new skills, and make money in more than one way over time.
Now, let's look at 15 real online hustles that you can start right away with no money. Each one has useful advice, how much money you can expect to make, and ways to make the most of your success.
1. Online Surveys: Get Paid to Share Your Opinion

Every year, companies spend billions on market research, and they are willing to pay regular people for their thoughts. Join sites like Swagbucks, InboxDollars, Survey Junkie, or Toluna. Users of these sites get paid to fill out surveys, watch ads, and take part in market research studies. It's a simple way to make money or gift cards when you're not busy, like when you're waiting in line, watching TV, or on your way to work.

To make the most money, sign up for more than one platform. Different survey sites target different groups of people, so having accounts on 4â€“5 platforms makes sure you always have surveys to fill out. Most users make between $50 and $150 a month if they keep using the service. Instead of penny surveys, look for surveys that pay $2 to $5 for 15 to 20 minutes of work. Also, make sure to fill out your profile completely on each platform. This will make you eligible for more surveys and help you make more money.

If you want to do well on surveys, you need to treat them like a small job. Set aside 30 minutes every day to focus on finishing surveys quickly, and keep track of which platforms pay the most for your age group. Some people say they make up to $300 a month by doing surveys and other things on these sites, like watching videos or playing games.
2. Websites for user testing: get paid to give feedback

Before a company launches or updates its website or app, it pays real people to test it. UserTesting, TryMyUI, and Userlytics are some of the platforms that pay $5 to $15 for each 20-minute test. Basically, you're a paid critic. All you have to do is say what you think out loud while you browse the site. This is great for people who like to think about their experiences and give helpful feedback.

It's easy to get started. Most platforms want you to take a sample test to prove that you can communicate well. When your profile is approved, tests will show up on your dashboard. The most important thing is to be honest and open about what you've been through. If something doesn't make sense to you, don't be afraid to say so. That's what businesses want to know. Screen recording software records your voice and face, so just be yourself and say everything you think.

Testers with experience can do 2 to 3 tests a day and make $300 to $500 a month. Some websites let you do live interviews for $60 to $90 an hour. User testing is great because you don't need any special skills, just honesty. Also, you'll learn about user experience design that could help you get other tech jobs.
3. Microtasking: Small Tasks, Steady Pay

Microtask platforms like Amazon Mechanical Turk, Clickworker, and Remotasks let people do small, repetitive tasks that computers aren't good at. These tasks include organizing data, tagging images, moderating content, transcribing audio, and proofreading short pieces of writing. It may not be glamorous work, but you don't need any experience; you just need to pay attention to detail and be reliable.

The biggest platform is Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk), which has thousands of tasks every day. Start with easier tasks to get more people to like you, then move on to harder tasks that pay more (Human Intelligence Tasks). Some workers make $8 to $12 an hour once they know which tasks are worth their time. Clickworker has similar tasks, like doing web research and writing. Remotasks is a growing field with a lot of demand for training AI systems through image annotation and data labeling.

Make a system to get the most money. To keep your approval rating above 98%, work during the busiest times (mornings in US time zones), use browser extensions that show you which tasks are most profitable, and always be very accurate. Many successful microtaskers make more than $1,000 a month by treating it like a part-time job and working smart.
4. Review of Apps and Websites: Pay to Beta Test

Developers need real users to find bugs, test features, and suggest changes before apps and websites go live. TesterWork and uTest are two sites that connect people who want to give feedback with companies that need it. You'll make money and build a portfolio of testing experience while learning how digital products work.

With more than a million testers around the world, uTest is the best in the business. Once you've made a profile, you'll get invites to test projects that are based on your interests and the devices you use. Each project has its own set of test cases and rules for reporting bugs. The more detailed your reports are, the more invitations you'll get. Testers get paid $10 to $50 for each project, and experienced testers can make $500 to $1,000 a month.

The learning curve is what makes this hustle worth it. You will learn how to report bugs, run test cases, and make sure software is of high quality, all of which are useful skills in the tech industry. Based on their testing portfolio, many successful testers go on to work as freelancers or full-time QA professionals.
5. Watch Ads and Videos: Make Money While You Relax

You can get small rewards for watching ads, movie trailers, and promotional videos on Swagbucks, InboxDollars, or PrizeRebel. It's not a full-time job, but it lets you make money while you do something you already do. Think of it as getting paid to look at your screen.

These sites work with advertisers who want people to see and interact with their ads. You watch videos, answer questions from time to time to show you're paying attention, and earn points that can be turned into cash or gift cards. Some platforms have playlists that play videos automatically, so you can make money while doing other things. The most important thing is to use more than one platform and run them while you do your normal online tasks.

Most users make between $20 and $50 a month, which isn't a lot, but the fact that it's passive makes it worth it. To get the most out of your time, watch videos and take surveys and do other things on the same platform. Some platforms have daily bonus streaks and referral programs that can greatly increase your earnings.
6. Get Paid to Read Emails: Easy Way to Make Money

Paid To Read Email and InboxPounds send users promotional emails and pay them to open and read them. It's an easy way to make a little extra money each month. You can read each email in a few seconds while you check your email, and they pay a few cents each.

It's a simple idea: advertisers pay these platforms to show off their products, and the platforms split that money with users who interact with the content. Surveys, product offers, and ads are all included in emails. To make the most money, click through every now and then, but for sure income, focus on the paid emails themselves.

Most people make $10 to $30 a month just from paid emails. You can make $50 to $100 a month by doing surveys, offers, and games on these platforms. It's not a lot of money, but it doesn't take much work and adds up over time. To handle these messages more effectively, create a separate email folder.
7. Cashback and rewards apps: Get paid to shop

When you shop online or in person, use apps like Rakuten, Dosh, and Ibotta. They give you money back on things you buy every day, like groceries, clothes, travel, and even eating out. It's like getting paid to buy things you would have bought anyway. Over time, these savings add up a lot.

Rakuten (which used to be called Ebates) works with thousands of stores to give you cash back on your online purchases. You can get 1% to 10% back on every purchase you make through their app or website. Every three months, they send a check or PayPal payment. Ibotta is all about groceries and everyday items. You can upload your receipts or link your loyalty cards to get cash back on certain items. When you shop at partner stores with linked credit cards, Dosh automatically gives you cashback. You don't have to do anything.

Cashback apps can help smart shoppers make $300 to $600 a year. For the biggest savings, use credit card rewards, store sales, and coupon codes together. The best part is that you don't have to do anything extra; you just have to use the apps before you go shopping. To get more bonuses, tell your friends about the app. Before you buy anything, check the apps to get the most money back.
8. Online Focus Groups: Get Paid to Share Your Thoughts

You can take part in paid focus groups on sites like Respondent.io or User Interviews. You can make $50 to $150 an hour in these sessions. You only need to tell researchers and companies that are doing market research what you think about products, services, or ideas. It's like getting paid to talk to people.

A moderator leads a focus group with 6 to 10 people who talk about certain topics. Sessions last between 60 and 90 minutes and pay between $50 and $200, depending on the topic and the qualifications of the participants. Some studies need people from certain groups, like business owners, parents, gamers, and so on. Make sure your profile is complete so you can get relevant invitations.

Respondent.io is great for B2B research because it pays professionals in a variety of fields $100 to $300 to take part in studies. User Interviews is all about doing consumer research with people from different backgrounds. Every week, apply to several studies, respond quickly to invitations, and show up ready. A lot of people who regularly take part in focus groups make between $500 and $1,000 a month.
9. AI Tools for Freelancers: The New Gig Economy

You don't need to know how to design or write anymore. You can make graphics with free tools like Canva or write content with ChatGPT. You can offer services like writing blogs, making social media posts, designing logos, or helping people online on Fiverr or Upwork. Begin with niches that don't have a lot of competition and build your reputation by doing good work and making clients happy.

To get started, make profiles on Fiverr and Upwork that show off your services. Use AI tools to make samples that show what you can do. For writing jobs, have ChatGPT make drafts of blog posts that you can change and improve. Use Canva templates to make professional graphics for your design work. Set low prices at first to get your first customers and build up reviews.

Freelancers who do well find niches that aren't being served well. Instead of writing in general, focus on writing product descriptions for Amazon sellers. Instead of doing general design work, focus on making graphics for local businesses' social media pages. Make packages that fix certain problems. If you work hard, you can make $500 to $2,000 a month in 3 to 6 months. The most important things are good communication, dependable delivery, and using AI to get things done quickly.
10. Make money by selling stock photos

You can start selling photos if you have a smartphone. Put original, high-quality pictures on Shutterstock, Adobe Stock, or iStock. As your portfolio grows, each download gives you a passive income in the form of royalties. The best part is that photos can make money for years after they are uploaded without any more work.

For stock photography, modern smartphone cameras are as good as professional ones. Focus on things that are good for business, like business ideas, lifestyle scenes, food, technology, nature, and abstract backgrounds. Make sure the lighting, focus, and composition of the photos are all good. Add keywords that are relevant to your images so that buyers can find them. This has a big effect on sales.

Begin by uploading 50 to 100 pictures to a number of different sites. Depending on the type of license and the platform, each sale makes $0.25 to $2.00. Individual earnings are small, but a big portfolio brings in steady passive income. Top contributors make more than $1,000 a month from their established portfolios. Upload regularly, learn what sells, and get better at taking pictures over time.
11. Check out products and get free stuff: Sample Rewards

Brands want real reviews to show that their products are good and to make them better. Tomoson and Influenster are two platforms that give you free products in exchange for feedback. It's a great way to try out products, save money, and gain influence in categories you like.

Influenster sends VoxBoxes full of sample products to members who fit certain demographic groups. Fill out your profile completely, interact with other members, and you'll get more boxes. Items include snacks, makeup, skin care products, and pet supplies. To stay eligible for future campaigns, be honest when you review on social media and retail sites.

Tomoson links companies that want to get more attention with reviewers. Look through the products that are available, apply to campaigns that interest you, and get free stuff in exchange for honest reviews. Some campaigns pay more than others. You won't get paid directly, but getting free stuff saves you money and can lead to paid reviewing jobs. A lot of reviewers save $100 to $300 a month on things they would have bought anyway.
12. Join affiliate programs that pay you to promote their products

Use Amazon Associates, Impact.com, or ShareASale affiliate links to promote products. Post links on Reddit, forums, or social media. You get paid a commission for every sale that comes through your link, and you don't need a website. It's performance-based marketing that grows with your efforts to promote.

It's easy to get started: sign up for Amazon Associates (it's free), make affiliate links for products you would naturally recommend, and share them where they make sense. You can write about products you love on social media, join niche forums where people are looking for recommendations, or start a free blog on sites like WordPress.com or Medium. The most important thing is to promote products that you really believe in.

Successful affiliates pick a few specific niches, like tech gadgets, fitness equipment, books, beauty products, and build audiences who are interested in those niches. Commissions range from 1% to 10% at Amazon, depending on the category. Specialized programs, on the other hand, pay 20% to 50%. New affiliates can make $100 to $500 a month in the first six months, while experienced affiliates can make a full-time income. The best part is that the content you make today can make you money for years to come.
13. Jobs for transcription: listen and type

Transcription is the process of turning audio recordings into text. Rev and GoTranscript will hire people who have never worked before. You can do it from anywhere and it's flexible. Platforms offer style guides and training, but being accurate and a good listener are also helpful. This is great for people who pay attention to details and can type well.

Rev does work for transcription, captions, and subtitles. To apply, take a sample test that shows how accurate you are. You can work whenever you want after you get the go-ahead. Just pick audio files that fit your schedule. Pay ranges from $0.30 to $1.00 per audio minute, depending on how hard it is and how quickly it needs to be done. Most people who do transcription part-time make between $100 and $300 a week.

To be successful at transcription, you need good equipment, comfortable headphones, a foot pedal to help you work faster, and strong typing skills (60+ WPM is ideal). Learn how to use keyboard shortcuts and transcription software. Pay attention to the quality of the audio clear recordings pay more because they are easier to transcribe. With experience, you can get higher-paying legal or medical transcription jobs that pay $20 to $30 an hour.
14. Online tutoring help: Share what you know

You can help students with their homework or answer simple questions on sites like StudyPool or JustAnswer. You don't need a teaching degree, but you do need to know a lot about a subject, like math, English, science, or how to study for a test. Answer questions, explain ideas, and get paid for each interaction. It's flexible and pays off.

StudyPool helps students who need help with their homework find tutors. Make a profile that shows off your skills, and then look through the questions that students have posted. To get more questions and build your reputation, give clear, helpful answers. The amount you pay depends on how hard the subject is and how good your tutor is. On average, it's $5 to $20 per question. The best tutors make $500 to $1,500 a month by working on weekends and evenings.

JustAnswer answers a wider range of questions, from legal and medical to tech support and pet care. Subject matter experts answer questions from paying customers, sharing what they know and have done. The platform checks your expertise by having you fill out an application, and then it connects you with questions that are relevant to your field. Depending on your skills and availability, you can make between $200 and $3,000 a month. Being responsive and communicating clearly are the most important things.
15. Write Product Descriptions: Basic Copywriting

Online sellers often need short descriptions of their products for their listings. You can sell this service on Fiverr or Upwork. Speak clearly and convincingly, use simple language, and focus on the features and benefits. This is a great way to get started as a freelance writer because you don't need any experience just good writing skills and a keen eye for detail.

To learn what works, look at product descriptions on Amazon and Etsy. Notice how good descriptions mix features (specifications) with benefits (what the customer gets). Make sample descriptions for things you own to show what you can do. Set up profiles for freelancers that offer packages, like 5 product descriptions for $X, 10 for $Y, and so on.

Depending on how hard the description is and how experienced you are, writing product descriptions can pay $5 to $50. Beginners make between $100 and $400 a month while they build their portfolios and client relationships. As you get better at your job, focus on certain areas like fashion, electronics, and home goods, and raise your rates. A lot of successful copywriters started out writing product descriptions before moving on to writing content that pays more.
Your Action Plan for Getting Started

You might feel overwhelmed with 15 choices. Pick two or three hustles that fit your interests and schedule. This week, make profiles on the right platforms. Spend 30 to 60 minutes every day learning and finishing your first tasks. Keep track of your money and time to see what works best for you. After 30 days, look at what's working and what isn't. Keep doing what's working, stop doing what's not, and add new hustles as you get more confident.

Keep in mind that consistency is better than intensity. To make money online with these methods, you don't have to work 12-hour days. You just have to show up regularly. Start small, get going, and watch your income grow. These side jobs won't make you rich right away, but they can help you make extra money, learn useful skills, and maybe even open up bigger doors.

Starting today is the most important thing to do. Choose one of these hustles, sign up, and do your first task. Planning won't get you anywhere; action will. Your journey to making money online starts now.

items: 15 Online Side Hustles You Can Start With Zero Skills or Investment
10 Free Ways to Start Earning Passive Income with Zero Dollar Investment
10 Free Ways to Start Earning Passive Income in 2025 (Even With $0)

faq.question: Is it possible to make money online without any experience?
faq.answer: Yes, a lot of online hustles are made for people who are just starting out and don't need any experience to get started. The most important thing is to pick the right chances and stick with them.

faq.question: Do you need money to start these online hustles?
faq.answer: No, you don't need a lot of money to start these online hustles. You can often use a smartphone or computer you already own. You can join all of the platforms listed for free.

faq.question: Are online hustles real or fake?
faq.answer: A lot of online hustles are real, but new people should do their homework on platforms to avoid scams. Stick to well-known sites with good reviews and clear records of payments. Don't ever pay to join a platform.

faq.question: How long does it take to make money online?
faq.answer: Some hustles can make money in a few days or weeks, while others take longer to grow, depending on how hard you work and how consistent you are. Survey sites and microtask platforms pay quickly, but freelance and affiliate income builds up over time.

faq.question: Are online hustles good for students and people who are just starting out?
faq.answer: Yes, these hustles are easy for beginners and good for students, stay-at-home parents, retirees, and anyone else who wants to make extra money on top of what they already do.

faq.question: How much money can I make doing these side jobs?
faq.answer: How much money you make depends a lot on how much time you put in, what hustles you choose, and how consistent you are. Most beginners make between $100 and $500 a month by using a mix of methods. Some people make $1,000 to $3,000 or more a month with experience and scaling.

faq.question: Is it possible to do more than one online job at once?
faq.answer: Of course. In fact, it's a good idea to combine several hustles to increase your income and make the most money. A lot of people who make money online use three to five different platforms at the same time.

faq.question: Can I use my phone instead of a computer?
faq.answer: You can do most hustles on your phone, but some are easier on a computer. Begin with what you already have. Many beginners start out with just their phones before getting better gear.
